pros: Lots of holidays where you don't have to be there.

I was a ChildLine counsellor and worked at NSPCC for 6 years. The management hierarchy is overbearing and obstructive to doing one's role. No-one is allowed to make decisions so all 'requests' for service improvement or staff management etc go up and up the management structure with nothing ever getting done to change things. If you're at the bottom of that structure you're screwed. 
This is a supposedly anti-bullying organisation and yet bullying is inherent in the way people are managed and left unsupported and victimised. 
In an emotional front-line role there was no supervision and no care for staff welfare. Everyone was regularly and repeatedly off sick. Staff turnover was high. Staff are actively told to 'put up and shut up' by management. This is the worst place I have ever worked and I would not go back if you gave me a million quid to do so.

pros:

Worthy cause
cons: As other reviewers have noted bullying is rife within this organisation, almost exclusively at manager level. There is a common pattern of redundancy and redeployment resulting in individuals who had been made redundant in another team being shoehorned into a position without the relevant experience, at the expense of more suited candidates. Complaints to HR regarding poor management remain unactioned and the staff survey is a pointless exercise - no change is effected or even acknowledged from the surveys. Long standing managers continue to lead teams with poor results and no system to review the efficacy of their leadership, leaving team members frustrated and disenfranchised.  There is limited scope for development with little to no training being offered and minimal progression. This is a very worthy cause but the whole organisation needs to be restructured and audited - I would wholeheartedly recommend that you stay away until they have acknowledged the problems highlighted by the many reviewers below and effected some positive change.
